I do worry, though, that this is one of those films that offers “yet another example of awards season being out of step with popular taste”, said Mark Kermode in The Observer. It’s not that “I didn’t like The Fabelmans; of course I did – I’m a film critic! But it’s also possibly the most lavishly mounted home movie ever made.” That, in the end, is both “its great strength and its fatal weakness”.
Shotgun Wedding
Romcom ***
“When I hear the words ‘wedding-themed romcom starring Jennifer Lopez’, I reach for my pistol,” said Leslie Felperin in the FT. “And yet Shotgun Wedding is a pleasant surprise.” Lopez plays Darcy, a middle-aged bride who is poised to marry her fiancé Tom (Josh Duhamel) at a luxury island resort in the Philippines, when a bunch of pirates – “not the jolly sort” – turn up and take the guests hostage. The direction from Jason Moore (Pitch Perfect) is “cake-knife sharp, while Mark Hammer’s script never wastes a gag”; but what really gives the film a boost “is the casting of sleeper agents in the supporting roles, such as the divine Jennifer Coolidge and protean D’Arcy Carden”.
This romcom has a “tough” and “cynical” exterior, which creates some problems, said Tim Robey in The Daily Telegraph. For instance, “when the whole cast attempt a heartfelt singalong, it’s so out of place you’re more likely to cringe than swoon”. On the other hand, the film is “mutinously bored with weddings”, which is refreshing, and it has “a punchy aerial climax that’s much better value than the average first dance”. In a “sickly-sweet genre”, Shotgun Wedding is “almost bracingly sour”.
There’s plenty to dislike about this film, said Calum Marsh in The New York Times: it tries too hard to be funny, and much of the dialogue feels “canned and phoney”. But Lopez is great; the love-hate rapport between her and Duhamel is “delightful” and convincing, and the whole thing is pleasingly simple.
Plane
Action ***
In this “punchy” action film, Gerard Butler plays a former RAF pilot who now makes a living flying commercial routes in Southeast Asia, said Wendy Ide in The Observer. His next trip matters more than most: it’s New Year’s Eve, and if all goes to plan, he will be reunited with his daughter at the end of it. Unfortunately for him, all does not go to plan, as there is bad weather to contend with as well as a shackled prisoner on board (Mike Colter) who is being extradited to stand trial for murder. The film may be “big, brawling and somewhat inelegant in approach”, but there’s no denying it’s also “an aviation fuel-powered good time. Think Die Hard meets Big Jet TV (or Fly Hard, if you prefer).”
I’m afraid it didn’t do it for me, said Kevin Maher in The Times. For one thing, the action is “poorly orchestrated” and the script is a bit B-movie (“I have a daughter, and I have every intention of hugging her again and making it home!” our hero vows at one point). For another, for a film called Plane, far too little time is actually spent on a plane. The film, co-scripted by the spy novelist Charles Cumming, is “preposterously macho”, said Matthew Bond in The Mail on Sunday, and it is a terrible advert for travel in Southeast Asia. But it’s also pure, “machine-gun-toting fun”. If you just relax into it, you may find it “surprisingly effective, despite an obvious lack of budget”.
Babylon
Drama ***
“The late 1920s in Hollywood was a time of bloated, self-indulgent excess,” said Brian Viner in the Daily Mail, so it is “fitting” that Damien Chazelle’s Babylon is “wide open to the same charge”. Still, “within its three hours-plus, there is lots to enjoy, including a bravura beginning and brilliant end”. The film opens in 1926 in Bel Air, where a hardworking Mexican immigrant (Diego Calva) is trying to transport an elephant to a riotous Hollywood party, setting the scene for “one of the more thunderous defecations you are ever likely to see on the big screen”. It is at this “orgy of decadence” that we meet Nelly (Margot Robbie), a “reckless, feckless” aspiring starlet, and Jack (Brad Pitt) a jaded matinee idol. From there, the film moves from “one visually ravishing set-piece” to the next, with little story to link them. There are some excellent cameos – including Tobey Maguire as a “gangland boss” – but the film “too often feels like an over-extended sketch show”.
“This 18-rated Tinseltown epic is the cinematic equivalent of a roller-coaster ride through a Jazz Age crack house that’s punctuated by screaming hysteria, suicides, orgies and human effluvia,” said Kevin Maher in The Times. “But don’t let that put you off.” Robbie has never been better, and the film has a wonderfully “dizzying, endorphin-drenched mood”. It flopped in the US, but with luck will find its audience here, as “it needs to be seen”. I don’t think it does, said Manohla Dargis in The New York Times. “The best that can be said” about this “self-indulgent” nonsense is that it shows that Hollywood studios still have money to burn. For all its “frantic action”, the film feels curiously “juiceless”, with everything in it “synced to the same monotonous, accelerated pace”.
Bank of Dave
Drama ***
Inspired by real events, Netflix’s Bank of Dave is a “feelgood underdog tale of ordinary folks sticking it to the Eton-educated financial elite”, said Wendy Ide in The Observer. Rory Kinnear stars as Dave Fishwick, the millionaire owner of a Burnley-based minibus dealership who, in 2011, responded to the reluctance of post-crash banks to lend to small businesses by creating his own, community-led model. “With its rabble-rousing regionalism (the word ‘London’ is delivered with such disdain, it might as well have been dipped in raw sewage), the film has much in common with the Cornish sea shanty picture Fisherman’s Friends, including, in Chris Foggin, a director.” A romantic subplot involving Dave’s niece (Phoebe Dynevor) is “surplus to requirements”, but Kinnear gives a “robustly likeable performance, somewhat redeeming this unashamedly formulaic crowd-pleaser”.
I wasn’t much taken by it, said Deborah Ross in The Spectator. The film is billed as a “true(ish)” story, and though Dave Fishwick is a real person, Google reveals that the story is “barely true at all”. There are so many “fictionalised elements – a romance, a courtroom showdown and, most bizarrely, the appearance of Def Leppard” – that the film becomes “distracted, and often loses sight of its main character”. Sure, “there are pockets of charm”, but “it’s all fairly one-dimensional, as is the script”. The minor characters do feel as if they have been “generated by an algorithm”, said Cath Clarke in The Guardian. Still, there are compensations. It’s a heartwarming story with a “greed-is-bad message” that few could take issue with – and Kinnear is “brilliant”. There’s a formula at work here, but it’s a pretty effective one.
Alice, Darling
Thriller ***
“Anna Kendrick is best known for her Pitch Perfect musical comedies”, but her latest project, Alice, Darling, is “intriguingly off-key”, said Robbie Collin in The Daily Telegraph. She plays Alice, a young professional “whose control-freak partner Simon (Charlie Carrick) has her perpetually tiptoeing through broken glass”. When he has a rough day at work, she is expected to snap at once into “soothing mode”; when she is out with friends, “her phone is forever chirruping away” as Simon badgers her with “needy hectoring and demands for raunchy photographs”. A weekend away, however, presents her with a chance to “detox” – and soon enough, her friends notice that something is badly wrong. Kendrick’s “default mood as an actress has always been sparkly-eyed perk”, so it’s a shock to see her so “paranoid and glazed”. Meanwhile, “thrillerish elements quietly but teasingly pile up” until the film reaches its “clever” if neat climax. This is a “modest” drama, but a “polished” one.
Alice, Darling “marks the directorial debut of Mary Nighy”, daughter of the actors Bill Nighy and Diana Quick, said Matthew Bond in The Mail on Sunday. For a first go, it’s an “impressive” achievement – but the film is also “a tough old watch”, and in particular it will no doubt test “anyone who’s had problems with eating disorders or self-harming”. I found it really rather dreary, said Kyle Smith in The Wall Street Journal. The film is full of “despondent music” and “close-ups of Alice’s tortured expressions”, and its “mood of dejection grows monotonous”. In the end, like Alice’s ever-solicitous friends, “the viewer gets stuck in her emotional quicksand”.
Tár
Drama ****
In this “riveting” film, Cate Blanchett stars as a world-famous conductor about to record Mahler’s Fifth Symphony, said Deborah Ross in The Spectator. There’s plenty of other classical music in the film – some Elgar, “a bit of Bach” – but to say it’s about music “would be like saying Citizen Kane is about tobogganing”. The film is “about power”, and whether it is “possible to separate art from artist”. If that sounds worthy, fear not: though Tár runs to 158 minutes, it “doesn’t drag for a single second”. We meet Lydia Tár at the height of her powers, as she is being interviewed on stage by Adam Gopnik of The New Yorker (played by Gopnik himself). “Her life looks beautiful”: the flat she shares with her wife (Nina Hoss) “could be an art gallery”, her jets are private and “her wardrobe is exquisite”. But it soon becomes clear that all is not as it seems. “Is she a sexual predator?” Who is Tár, really? As the plot unfolds, the film becomes “as tense as a thriller”, driven by Blanchett’s “insanely glorious” performance. If she doesn’t get an Oscar for it, “I’ll eat my hat”.
Blanchett is “electrifying”, agreed Wendy Ide in The Observer, but the “genius” of Tár lies in the way “the film-making echoes the treacherously seductive and mercurial nature of its central character”. Director Todd Field (Little Children, In the Bedroom) makes sure that you never quite know what you’re watching, whether it’s the “slow-motion car crash” of a #MeToo-type cancellation drama or “a supernatural thriller”. Whatever it is, the results are “phenomenal”. This is one of those films that “isn’t interested in offering anyone an easy ride”, said Andy Lea in the Daily Express. And while it can be “pretentious” and “infuriating”, you may find that it gets under your skin.
M3GAN
Horror ****
“A supremely entertaining addition to the sub-genre of ‘bad toy’ horror films”, M3GAN is about an AI-powered doll that goes rogue, said Alistair Harkness in The Scotsman. M3GAN (short for “Model 3 Generative Android”) was developed by an engineer at a toy company in Seattle, who finds herself looking after her 11-year-old niece (Violet McGraw) when she is abruptly orphaned. The engineer (Allison Williams) isn’t great with kids, so she brings a prototype of M3GAN home to watch over the child. It soon transpires, of course, that M3GAN is a murderous “four-foot version” of the Terminator, albeit one that looks more like Taylor Swift than Arnold Schwarzenegger. She has some good qualities as a babysitter: she encourages her charge to use a coaster, for instance; but when she sees her being bullied, she goes nuts and rips the bully’s ears off. It’s very “silly”, but it’s great fun, and is full of good jokes as well as some “jump scares”.
“Splendidly directed by Gerard Johnstone and wittily scripted by Akela Cooper, this is not quite a horror film, not quite a slasher movie, and not quite a dark comedy, but a terrifically enjoyable amalgam of all three,” said Brian Viner in the Daily Mail. Perhaps above all, it’s “a mischievous satire about artificial intelligence, with rumbling echoes of Frankenstein’s monster”. I didn’t expect to like it – “but I did, very much”. There are “fleeting moments of gore” in M3GAN, said Kevin Maher in The Times, but at its core it’s an old-fashioned, “family-friendly horror”, whose main concern is to explore “the deleterious impact of modern technology” on parenting. “It all ends with a suitably demented finale and an obvious set-up for a sequel. Which, for once, will be welcomed.”
Enys Men
Folk horror ***
“With his breakthrough feature Bait, in 2019”, the Cornish film-maker Mark Jenkin showed himself to be a creator of “daringly strange expressionist cinema”, said Peter Bradshaw in The Guardian. Now, he has refined his “unique, stripped-down style for an eerie prose-poem of a movie about loneliness”. Set in 1973, Enys Men stars Mary Woodvine as an unnamed woman living on a remote Cornish island, where she monitors a species of wildflower that grows by a cliff. Every day she inspects the flowers; at night, she reads, and listens to the radio. This “steady state of hermit-like seclusion is disrupted”, however, when she sees lichen emerging from one of the flowers – and finds it growing on her skin, too. “This is not a scary film in the generic sense, but there is something unsettling in the simple spectacle of solitude: no company, no television, no shopping, no diversions.” Enys Men “forces you to look in on yourself, and that indeed will take you to the brink of something that feels like madness”. It’s an unusual film, made with “real artistry”.
If you have “mainstream tastes”, you may find this film “too experimental”, said Matthew Bond in The Mail on Sunday. But I found it a “strange and atmospheric” joy. “Deliberately left rough around the edges, it also features the best use of red rainwear since Don’t Look Now.” It’s true that “some will be left confused – even frustrated – by a narrative that slips dexterously between dreams and reality”, said Mark Kermode in The Observer. The best approach, I think, is “simply to let Enys Men drown you in its intensely sensory spell; to feel it rather than watch it”.
Empire of Light
Drama **
“There are plenty of themes swimming around in Sam Mendes’s sprawling, uneven Empire of Light”, but there are few coherent ideas to link them up, said Wendy Ide in The Observer. Set in an English seaside town in the 1980s, it stars Olivia Colman as Hilary, a troubled front-of-house manager at a run-down cinema, who forms a romantic bond with Stephen, a much younger, black employee (Micheal Ward). “Colman is a phenomenal talent and Ward shows potential”, but the film “awkwardly slings together mental health issues and racially motivated violence”, then tries to tie it all up with a “glib point about the unifying power of cinema”. Despite the efforts of veteran cinematographer Roger Deakins, who gives the film welcome “visual flair”, it’s just not that good.
In Empire of Light we finally get an answer to the all-important question: “Can Olivia Colman save any film she’s in?” Unfortunately, said Deborah Ross in The Spectator, the answer is no. “Peculiarly soulless, pedestrian and plodding”, this film has been billed as a “love letter to cinema” – but hardly anyone in it seems to watch films, let alone love them, and you get the feeling the story could “just as easily have been set in a butcher’s shop”. A better script would have helped. During a sexual encounter, we hear: “Your arse feels so good in my hands.” This is Mendes’s first project as the sole writer, “and I’m not saying he should be banned from the keyboard, but maybe friends and family could be tactfully discouraging?” I was really looking forward to Empire of Light, and I found it a “mild disappointment”, said Brian Viner in the Daily Mail. You never quite believe that there is a “sexual and emotional connection” between Hilary and Stephen. Still, it’s “perfectly watchable”.
Till
Drama ****
“I’ve seen enough films about the American civil rights movement to have heard the name Emmett Till many times,” said Matthew Bond in The Mail on Sunday. “But to my shame, I’ve never known his dreadful story.” Thanks to Till, I do now, and “I’ll never forget it”. Till (played here by Jalyn Hall) was 14 years old when he travelled from his home in Chicago in 1955 to visit relatives in Mississippi. Unschooled in the entrenched racism of the Deep South, he allegedly made a cheeky wolf whistle to a young white woman in a shop; days later, he was dragged out of the house, tortured, killed and thrown into a river. Danielle Deadwyler is superb as Till’s mother, Mamie, who insisted on holding an open-casket funeral so that the whole world could see what had been done to her son. Till is “an immensely tough watch”, but it’s powerful too, and sure to be a contender in awards season.
This is one of those films that “hangs on the intensity of its central performance”, said Kevin Maher in The Times; thankfully, Deadwyler “is a revelation”. Credit is also due to director Chinonye Chukwu, who vividly conveys the venomous racism of the era, while wisely keeping Till’s murder off-screen (though we do hear it). “The weight of Emmett Till’s murder, the horror of it – as well as both the history that preceded his death and that which followed it – is monumental, impossible, really, for one movie,” said Manohla Dargis in The New York Times. Rather than trying to encompass it all, Chukwu captures a sense of it via “fugitive moments” and “explosive gestures”. In the end, what makes Till “cut deeply” is its insistence that, before Emmett was “a victim of racism and an emblem for change”, he was a son, a grandson, a friend: “a beautiful, loving and loved child”.
A Man Called Otto
Drama **
“A Man Called Otto, which has Tom Hanks scowling in anoraks as a widower at the end of his tether, could well be a candidate for the most innocuous film ever made,” said Tim Robey in The Daily Telegraph. “An ostensible comedy-drama in which neither facet makes much of an impression”, the film is a remake of the Swedish hit A Man Called Ove (2015), which had an enjoyable “level of deadpan Scandi glumness” that is missing here. Hanks plays Otto, a retired curmudgeon whose rigid routine is disrupted when a family moves onto his street and tries to befriend him. “If you’ve seen Eastwood’s Gran Torino or Nicolas Cage in The Weather Man, you’ll know the sort of cranky redemption arc we’re eventually in for, but this is the flat-packed, self-assembly-kit version – more likely to exacerbate a mild depression than warm the cockles.”
The trouble is, Hanks just doesn’t convince as a curmudgeon, said Peter Bradshaw in The Guardian. He’s too lovable. And with “his fierce short haircut and blank, open face, he looks very familiar. Not grump, but Gump.” More troubling still are the “jarring and baffling” scenes in which he attempts to take his own life, which are not done seriously enough to “do justice to the subject”, but are not “dark enough for scabrous black comedy” either, so they land very awkwardly indeed. The film is formulaic, and often cloying, said Thomas Floyd in The Washington Post, but I found “something soothing about its wholehearted vision of the ‘found’ family” and its virtues. A Man Called Otto is a “cosy crowd-pleaser” – and there’s “nothing wrong with that”.
I Wanna Dance With Somebody
Drama ***
Whitney Houston’s “tragic slide” from America’s sweetheart to drug addict has been exhaustively documented over the years, said James Mottram in Metro. But I Wanna Dance With Somebody, which was authorised by the singer’s estate and makes liberal use of her music, “largely ducks the muckracking, preferring instead to celebrate her talent”. Houston is played (and lip-synced) by Naomi Ackie who, despite being from northeast London, manages “right from the off” to embody the New Jersey girl who just wanted to make “great big songs”. The film charts how Houston became a pop sensation, with the help of record producer Clive Davis (Stanley Tucci), and though it does cover her untimely death, aged 48, it is never depressing, which is “quite the feat” from director Kasi Lemmons. It is admittedly a “sanitised, 12A version” of her story, but it offers a “dignified” and very watchable look at “one of the greatest divas we ever had”.
There are enough sequins and rhinestones to fill “a playpit of sparkle for all the toddlers of the world”, said Leslie Felperin in the FT; so “what’s the downside, you may ask”. Well, the film “doesn’t build much of a case for why you should admire, let alone love and mourn, the late chanteuse”. Amounting to little more than “one long, frantic montage”, it fails to nail “what was so special about Houston’s musical talent”. And it doesn’t tell us much about her as a person, either, said Brian Viner in the Daily Mail; it has been suggested that Houston was molested as a child, and had a tricky relationship with her mother, neither of which are addressed here. But if you “just want an excuse to listen again to that incredible voice”, I Wanna Dance With Somebody “is worth your embrace”.
The Pale Blue Eye
Thriller ***
This “star-studded, gothically-inclined drama” set in 1830s America sees a jaded detective, Augustus Landor (Christian Bale), summoned to a military academy to solve a mystery, said Matthew Bond in The Mail on Sunday. A cadet appears to have taken his own life, but his corpse has been mutilated, and his commanding officer wants Landor to find out why. He is initially reluctant, but “perks up” when he meets a strange young cadet – “one Edgar Allan Poe, no less”, played by Harry Melling (Dudley Dursley in the Harry Potter films) – who has some useful insights into what might be going on. Director Scott Cooper piles on the “bleak, wintry atmosphere”, and “draws an interesting range of performances” from a cast that includes Toby Jones, Gillian Anderson and Charlotte Gainsbourg. A word of “gentle warning”, though: the story heads somewhere really quite odd, as might be expected “from a drama that places Poe, one of the great writers of gothic horror, at its heart”.
The “representation police” will surely loathe this “twisty, turny” film, since its female characters are mostly “prostitutes, harridans, nutty mums or victims”, said Kevin Maher in The Times. But if you can get past that, there’s plenty to enjoy. The script is “beautiful” and the performances are impeccable, “with each actor engaged in the kind of commitment that only adds to the film’s sense of existential dread”. It “looks wonderfully atmospheric”, but I’m afraid I didn’t love it, said Wendy Ide in The Observer. For the first hour, it’s a “deliciously morbid mystery”, let down only by “some slightly ropey American accents” from some of the British actors in supporting roles; but then the story disintegrates into a “lurid and rather silly final act”.
Corsage
Drama ****
An “austere” German-language drama, Corsage imagines the home life of the Habsburg Empress Elisabeth of Austria in 1877, the year of her 40th birthday, said Peter Bradshaw in The Guardian. The Kaiserin (Vicky Krieps) is portrayed as a “woman of passions and discontents” who faced “icy distaste from the court and the family of her unfaithful husband, Franz Joseph” (Florian Teichtmeister), and cut a lonely figure in the “huge, chilly salons and gloomy dining rooms” in which she eked out her existence. In many ways a “study in anger”, the film, directed by Marie Kreutzer, is sustained by Krieps’s “exhilaratingly fierce” performance, and successfully explores “how women are isolated and restricted by whatever status” they manage to acquire.
Corsage isn’t “yet another film about a woman being done over by bad royals”, said Deborah Ross in The Spectator. “It’s more a take on celebrity culture and no longer being what is wanted” – and I found it “mesmerisingly sad”. It’s rather “metaphor-heavy” (there are lots of decaying rooms, and clips of Elisabeth putting on such tight corsets she can “barely breathe”), but it’s “gorgeously photographed” and builds into a “complex portrait of a restless spirit”. There have been films about Elisabeth’s life before, said Robbie Collin in The Daily Telegraph, but none has been in such an “ironised, icy cool register” as Corsage. Krieps plays the empress with “delicious hauteur”, yet the brilliance of her performance “lies partly in the way she renders this prickly character sympathetic”. You’ll be “unswervingly” on Elisabeth’s side – even if “you’re never quite certain she’d be on yours”.
